title: French alpine hunters train in Norway's Arctic: 'Extreme cold is the Russians' natural playground. We have to be up to par'
summary: Since Finland's accession in April 2023, NATO has to secure a further 1,300 kilometers of border with Russia and relearn how to operate in extreme climatic conditions.

title: Macron announces bill allowing 'aid in dying,' under 'strict conditions'
summary: In an interview with two newspapers, President Emmanuel Macron announced legislation to allow eligible patients to administer a lethal product, alone or with assistance.

title: Haiti: US embassy evacuates non-essential staff amid gang violence
summary: The US military airlifted US government workers overnight, but the embassy in Port-au-Prince remains open. The International Organization for Migration said the capital was 'under siege' by gangs who are demanding the prime minister resign.

title: Senegal's political crisis takes a toll on the tourism sector
summary: With the first round of the presidential election set for March 24 and Ramadan beginning on Sunday, hoteliers are concerned about the continued significant drop in the occupancy rates of their establishments.

title: Novo Nordisk, the Danish pharmaceutical giant boosted by its anti-obesity medication
summary: Since the launch of Wegovy, its weight loss treatment, the century-old laboratory has seen its sales soar. On Thursday, March 7, its market capitalization, at 566 billion euros, surpassed that of Tesla.

title: 'The 96th Oscars ceremony will attempt to make us believe in the resurrection of Hollywood'
summary: The success of 'Barbie' and 'Oppenheimer,' which generated record profits and racked up 21 nominations at the Oscars, is an exception in a film industry now dominated by streaming platforms, observes Le Monde's TV columnist Thomas Sotinel.

title: UK: Government announces £117 million security funding for Muslim sites
summary: The security measures will include technology such as CCTV, alarm systems, and perimeter fencing. A further £31 million will also be made available to ensure the protection of democratic processes and institutions in response to growing extremist threats.

title: Al-Qaeda in Yemen announces death of leader Khalid Batarfi
summary: Batarfi had appointed his successor back in February 2020, following the death of his predecessor, Qassim al-Rimi, in a US drone strike or Yemen.

title: No more Pushkin, Dostoyevsky, or Tolstoy: Ukrainian libraries clean out shelves
summary: Russian authors have disappeared from the shelves of most Ukrainian libraries since the 2022 invasion. Librarians are not taking these decisions lightly, but rather out of a sense of patriotism.

title: Portugal: Exit polls show center-right ahead in general election, far-right soars
summary: The election was called after Socialist Prime Minister Antonio Costa, 62, unexpectedly resigned in November following an influence-peddling probe that involved a search of his official residence and the arrest of his chief of staff. Though Costa himself was not accused of any crime, he decided not to run again.

title: Early Van Gogh sold for several millions of euros at Dutch art fair
summary: The painting "Tête de paysanne à la coiffe blanche," which was offered for 4.5 million euros at TEFAF, has been sold on Sunday to a museum outside the European Union.

title: Six Nations: France back to winning ways in Wales
summary: Gaël Fickou scored five tries and Thomas Ramos kicked 20 points as Les Bleus defeated the Welsh 45-24.

title: Ukraine furious at Pope Francis's call to 'raise the white flag'
summary: After the pope's interview with a Swiss broadcaster, in which he said Kyiv should 'have the courage to raise the white flag,' the Vatican issued a statement insisting he intended to mean  'a truce reached with the courage of negotiation.'

title: Denmark establishes itself as one of Europe's biggest donors to Ukraine
summary: Since the start of the Russian invasion, the Scandinavian kingdom has announced arms deliveries worth €4.5 billion. The country's commitment is based on unwavering consensus.

title: Saudi Arabia says Ramadan moon spotted, meaning fasting starts Monday for many
summary: The holy Muslim month of fasting will start on Monday for many Sunni-majority countries, while Iran and some others said it would begin on Tuesday.

title: Samuel Eto'o under fire as head of Cameroon's football federation
summary: The former striker's first 26 months as president have been plagued by scandal and controversy. In particular, he has been criticized for solitary decision-making.

title: American cyclist Matteo Jorgenson wins Paris-Nice race
summary: Team Visma-Lease a Bike's rider became the third American to win the eight-stage race.

title: Maia Sandu, president of Moldova: 'There is nothing more important than helping Ukraine win this war'
summary: The leader of this country of 2.6 million inhabitants bordering Ukraine believes that its European integration is a question of 'survival.'

title: Three bodies found, four missing, after floods snare cars in southern France
summary: The search for four missing individuals, including a father and his two children, was suspended on Sunday, March 10, at nightfall, after three initial victims of the severe weather that swept through the Southeast were found in Gard.

title: On Ukraine, France and Germany can't agree to speak with one voice
summary: Russia's invasion of Ukraine has exacerbated a rivalry for leadership between Chancellor Olaf Scholz and President Emmanuel Macron, while revealing the profound differences in strategic approaches between the two countries.

title: Oscars 2024: 'Oppenheimer' wins best picture, Emma Stone takes best actress
summary: Christopher Nolan, the indisputable Hollywood hitmaker whose ambitious and challenging blockbusters entice mainstream audiences and cult followings alike, finally confirmed his artistic pre-eminence with the Oscar-sweeping "Oppenheimer."

title: Niger, 2024 growth champion: mirage or reality?
summary: The country is expected to experience the highest growth rate in Africa in 2024. Faced with inflation and sanctions that have weakened the economy, the oil revenue offers hope for recovery.

title: How the 'Anatomy of a Fall' team campaigned for the Oscars
summary: The independent American distributor Neon is backing Justine Triet's feature film in the race for statuettes, notably in the Best Picture category. However, the budget was just $3 million, whereas its big rivals have spent $25 million.

title: Paris 2024: Lille dreams of becoming the handball and basketball capital of the Olympics
summary: To welcome international teams from both disciplines in Villeneuve-d'Ascq, the Northern metropolis has invested 15 million euros and built an Olympic village.

title: Why Ramadan has taken root among young Muslims
summary: The fasting month is due to start on Monday, March 11. For those under 25, this spiritual time is seen as a 'challenge' and an opportunity to assert themselves while expressing their affiliation with a community.

title: European elections poll: Far right 13 points ahead of Macron's camp, gap widening
summary: Marine Le Pen's Rassemblement National party is broadening and solidifying its electorate, Emmanuel Macron's coalition is losing voters, according to a poll conducted for Le Monde, Cevipof, the Fondation Jean Jaurès and the Institut Montaigne.

title: Gaza: New accounts of the 'flour massacre'
summary: On February 29, 118 Palestinians were killed and 760 injured while waiting for a humanitarian aid convoy, according to the local Ministry of Health. Survivors tell Le Monde they were the target of Israeli fire.

title: Oscars 2024: 'Oppenheimer' triumphs, while 'Anatomy of a Fall' wins best screenplay
summary: Christopher Nolan's biopic won seven statuettes, including best picture, best director, best actor for Cillian Murphy and best supporting actor for Robert Downey Jr.

title: News agencies retract Princess of Wales photo over 'concerns' about image authenticity
summary: Britain's national news agency and others retracted the first official picture of Kate since she underwent surgery in January over 'concerns about the image.'

title: Portuguese left suffers setback in elections marked by rise of far right
summary: Following Sunday's early elections, the far-right Chega party quadrupled its seats in a fragmented assembly with no stable majority.

title: Macron endorses 'aid in dying' bill
summary: The French president on Sunday declared himself in favor of assisted dying under 'strict conditions.' Details of the 10-year plan for palliative care, however, were postponed until the end of March.

title: Rumours of Aya Nakamura singing Edith Piaf at Paris Olympics sparks far-right backlash
summary: Far-right groups say that the French-Malian superstar does not represent France.

title: Paris Fashion Week was like a Baroque painting. Does anyone care?
summary: During one of the industry's biggest events, held from February 26 to March 5, the catwalk often spilled over into the front rows, as evidenced by the line-up of celebrities at the March 2 Vivienne Westwood show.

title: 'Dignity in defeat has been at the heart of the Palestinian tragedy'
summary: In his weekly column for Le Monde, Jean-Pierre Filiu writes that peace with Israel will depend on the demand of the Palestinian people for dignity finally being met.

title: 2024 European elections: Who is running in France?
summary: France will vote on June 9  to elect 81 members of the European Parliament, as the 27 member states of the European Union renew the assembly's 720 seats.

title: Ethiopia's hidden famine needs national and global attention
summary: Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed refuses to acknowledge the serious food crisis affecting Tigray, in the north of the country.

title: One in three French women live in rural areas, yet they remain a public policy blind spot
summary: The 11 million French women who live in the countryside are often overlooked, despite facing difficulties accessing employment, public services and healthcare.

title: Famine in Ethiopia's Tigray has become a political battle
summary: Regional authorities have declared a state of famine in the region, but Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed has refused to acknowledge the serious food crisis.
